title: Pcbnew: locking object with 'L' hotkey cannot be undone (lp:#1840770)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840770) created by **Wayne Stambaugh (stambaughw)**
```
Steps to produce:

1. Lock any lockable object (footprints, tracks, and vias tested) using the
'L' hotkey.
2. Notice that the undo toolbar button and menu entry are disabled so undo
cannot be performed.

Locking the above objects using the properties dialog can be undone as
expected.  This affects both the master and 5.1 branches.
```

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840769) created by **follower (78luphr0rnk2nuqimstywepozxn9kl19tqh0tx66b5dki1xxsh5mkz9gl21a5rlwfnr8jn6ln0m3jxne2k9x1ohg85w3jabxlrqbgszpjpwcmvkbcvq9spp6z3w5j1m33k06tlsfszeuscyt241h-launchpad-a811i2i3ytqlsztthjth0svbccw8inm65tmkqp9sarr553jq53in4xm1m8wn3o4rlwaer06ogwvqwv9mrqoku2x334n7di44o65qze67n1wneepmidnuwnde1rqcbpgdf70gtqq2x9thj5tlcsac)**
```
The patch
https://git.launchpad.net/kicad/patch/?id=37741048cef0d1623d90eeed43bf537de375e938
for the issue https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1813964 appears to have
created a new bug where now polylines are closed even when they shouldn't
be.

I encountered this issue plotting an SVG of this project schematic:
https://github.com/bobbarnes1981/mod_synth/tree/3c8d33dbccd27c43dd53195eee7b6646931202e2/mod_synth_seq/schematic


An earlier KiCad version (5.0) plotted the schematic correctly:

```

```

I first encountered the incorrect rendering with KiCad version 5.1.2 (which
also had another black & white SVG plotting bug):

```

```
Here is a partial diff between the correct plot in version 5.0 and the
incorrect plot in 5.1.2 (note the addition of the "Z"):

```
@ @ -10467,19 +11446,23@ @
 <g style="fill:#000000; fill-opacity:0.0;
 stroke:#000000; stroke-width:100; stroke-opacity:1;
 stroke-linecap:round; stroke-linejoin:round;">
-<polyline fill="none;"
-points="91500,14250
+<path style="fill:#000000; fill-opacity:0.0;
+stroke:#000000; stroke-width:100; stroke-opacity:1;
+stroke-linecap:round; stroke-linejoin:round;fill:none"
+d="M 91500,14250
 91750,14500
 92000,14250
 92500,14250
-" />
-<polyline fill="none;"
-points="92500,13250
+Z" />
+<path style="fill:#000000; fill-opacity:0.0;
+stroke:#000000; stroke-width:100; stroke-opacity:1;
+stroke-linecap:round; stroke-linejoin:round;fill:none"
+d="M 92500,13250
 91250,13250
 91250,14250
 91000,14500
 90750,14250
-" />
+Z" />
 </g>
```


This example SVG file patch results in a correct plotting (for that portion
of the component):

```
--- /<path>/mod_synth_seq--kicad-linux-nightly--bw-without-title-border--
half-buggy.svg        2019-08-19 23:31:55.000000000 +1200
+++ /<path>/mod_synth_seq--kicad-linux-nightly--bw-without-title-border--
half-buggy--edit.svg  2019-08-20 23:48:01.000000000 +1200
@ @ -11462,7 +11462,7@ @
 91250,14250
 91000,14500
 90750,14250
-Z" />
+" />
 </g>
 <g style="fill:#000000; fill-opacity:0.0;
 stroke:#000000; stroke-width:60; stroke-opacity:1;
```

Note that the code patch in question removed a conditional check
(potentially due to the fact that the later "Close/(fill) the path" comment
didn't really reflect what the last piece of code was doing):

```
@ @ -492,16 +505,7@ @ void SVG_PLOTTER::PlotPoly( const
std::vector<wxPoint>& aCornerList,
         fprintf( outputFile, "%d,%d\n", (int) pos.x, (int) pos.y );
     }

-    // ensure the shape is closed, for filled shapes (that are closed
polygons):
-    // (svg does not close automatically a polygon
-    if( aCornerList.front() != aCornerList.back() && aFill != NO_FILL )
-    {
-        pos = userToDeviceCoordinates( aCornerList.front() );
-        fprintf( outputFile, "%d,%d\n", (int) pos.x, (int) pos.y );
-    }
-
-    // Close/(fill) the path
-    fprintf( outputFile, "\" /> \n" );
+    fprintf( outputFile, "Z\" /> \n" );
 }
```

I'm guessing but haven't verified that moving the output of the "Z" back
inside the original conditional may fix the issue--but I don't know if that
would have any unintended consequences elsewhere.
```

title: Recent nightly releases of Kicad  PCBnew  has broken the  mouse highlighted trace drag feature (lp:#1840694)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840694) created by **Joe Silva (silvajoe65)**
```
Recent nightly releases of Kicad  PCBnew "kicad-r14050.551eb56da-x86_64"
has broken the mouse highlighted trace drag feature. The trace is moved
rather than dragged when it is highlighted by mouse.  KiCad PCBnew
interactive Router settings is set to drag but mouse highlighted traces no
longer drags when trying to re-position the trace. The traces are moved
thus breaking connections. This dragging feature worked on releases
"kicad-r13967.885497ec1-x86_64" and earlier. I have attached a picture to
show the problem.
```

title: PCBNew Fatal Crash deleting locked items most recent release (lp:#1840590)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840590) created by **Brian Piccioni (br0an)**
```
I know this bug has been reported but is was marked fixed and I have a test
file (attached)

There appears to be 2 bugs in PCBNew. One is serious and causes a fatal
crash.

1) Deleting locked track fragment@ 146.05 134.5946 causes a fatal crash. I
had numerous other crashes, apparently while deleting locked items but
those seemed to be hit and miss as I tried to narrow the bug down. The bug
would always appear the same way: instead of the "Delete again ..." message
coming up a grey box will appear and PCBNew crashes.

The happens 100% of the time with my file (attached) whether I run PCBNew
standalone or from Kicad

2) In order to try and narrow down the nature of the bug I ran PCBNew
standalone. I notice that the layers manager goes wonky and there is a long
delay in loading the board. This does not occur when running PCBNew from
Kicad. I will report a separate bug.
```

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840459) created by **NhatKhai (nhatkhai)**
```
I would like 2 thing from "File Name" text box from hierarchy schematic
box.
1) A combo box / drop box with user define list of values.
2) A browse button to help user pick and choose existing schematic file.

These allow use cases where user want to switch to difference design style
or other schematic file quickly. And it is useful for me in case I need to
so many sub circuitry simulations without having create/setup so many
projects. Where they often share a set of "+spice" directive from the root
schematic.

NOTE: "+pspice" should be reserved instead of remove from 5.x. Because this
directive is much faster for commenting in/out a large block of directive
text, and it can be use full to stupidly treat text as string that put
directly into netlist for many may other simulation instead of try to be
smart for parsing it.
May be "+pspice" and "-spice" for dump include in netlist, and "#pspice"
for not include in netlist. And other for "smart" parsing like current 5.x
doing would fit more people use cases to me. If "#pspice", I can tell Kicad
do not "smart" parsing some of my directive text. Because I want to keep
them there for or the use cases. Just add this
https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1840460
```

title: Eeschema has Save and Save All (lp:#1840383)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840383) created by **Seth Hillbrand (sethh)**
```
The horizontal toolbar is tied to "Save All" while the Hotkey is set to
"Save"

While we do use a document-based file format, I don't think that there's a
good usecase for differentiating between "Save" and "Save All".  In a
multi-document interface, you might have multiple, /independent/ documents
open at once, so having two kinds of Save makes sense.

Eeschema can never have multiple independent sheets open.  They can only be
hierarchically linked, so allowing one sheet to be saved but another to not
be invites more trouble than it is meant to avoid.
```

title: Y-coordinate inversion when attempting to move a pin (lp:#1840154)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840154) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
When I move a pin the cursor jumps to the opposite Y coordinate.  For
example if the pin I'm moving is located at Y = 2.00", when I place cursor
over the pin and hit "M" keyboard shortcut, the cursor will jump to Y =
-2.00.  If the pin is located far enough from the 0 coordinate, it gets
really confusing because after the jump everything disappears and the only
```

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840148) created by **Piotr Gałka (piotrgalka)**
```
I think it would be useful if the symbol description would be seen (not
editable) in dialog box shown when pressing 'E' at symbol at schematic.
In version 5.1.4 it is not.

At schematic I use the same (short) name for different elements (100n is
100n/16V (0402) or 100n/50V (0603) or 100n/100V (0805) ).
When adding no problem - description informs me if I place the right one (I
have them in separate libraries).
But if some time later I won't to check if I used the right one I don't see
the voltage, but only the footprint. And I don't remember which footprint
means which voltage for all capacitor values.
To see description would help.
If I add custom field its value is the same for all aliases so to use it
(it is seen when 'E') I would have to not have capacitors with the same
footprint defined as aliases.

Temporarily I decided to copy capacitor descriptions to Datasheet field,
what is generally not a right solution.
```

title: Implement support for STEP compression (lp:#1839893)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1839893) created by **Harvie (harvie)**
```
packages3d directory takes 5GB of my diskspace, while i've installed it
from ~300MB archlinux package. Can you please add support for compression?
There are compressed versions of both VRLM and STEP, using extensions
.wrl.gz and .stpZ, both supported by FreeCAD.

I think it would make sense to support this. Maybe you can simplify and
just use .wrl.gz and .step.gz.

I suggest to implement this in such way, that user will enter path to
uncompressed model (without ".gz") and if there's no such file, kicad can
take a second look to version with ".gz" suffix. So it will be possible to
compress whole library without having to change existing PCB files or
limiting ability to modify the models without having to recompress them
every time.

BTW why library contains all models in two formats? Can't we just stick to
one of them? I guess that STEP is more modern, but VRLM takes 4 times less
space.
```

title: Open/New Project file dialogs should use current project folder's parent (lp:#1839439)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1839439) created by **eelik (eelik)**
```
KiCad isn't designed for projects inside other projects. Most often, I
think, a project is in the same level in the file hierarchy than other
projects. Therefore opening certain file dialogs, namely Open Project and
Create Project (at least), with the current project folder pre-opened, is a
bit inefficient. I work with lots of small projects, changing between them
and creating new, so every time I have to go one level up in the file
hierarchy before I can select or create the wanted project.

I would appreciate if those dialogs were opened with the upper level folder
pre-opened.
```

title: eeschema cut and paste annotation lost (lp:#1839348)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1839348) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
Cutting a part of a schematic to paste it somewhere else looses components
annotation.

To reproduce:
  Select a component
  cut it with ctrl-x or right-click-menu->cut
  paste it with ctrl-V or right-click-menu->paste.
  The component annotation of the pasted items is lost.

This can be a problem when on complex projects you have to re-organize
schematics but you have yet routed the board: re-annotating the components
generates a schematic that is not in-sync with the pcb and re-syncronizing
it (F8) with different annotation may be is not so easy (did not try it: I
have a too complex board).


In "copy-paste"operation is correct to clear components annotation, since
without doing that we would end up to a "duplicate references", but in
"cut-paste" the annotation should be kept.

May be the easiest way to handle this correctly is:
 -after a cut or copy the reference of the components in clipboard should
be reset only if that reference exist in the project (this handles also the
case where cut is followed by more than one paste)
Since a copy does not remove the components the cut-paste, copy-paste, cut-
paste-paste-paste, copy-paste-paste-paste... are all handled the same way.

On the 5.1.2 version the cut+paste works correctly without loosing
annotation.
On the 5.1.4 version the cut+paste works correctly without loosing
annotation.

May be this issue is related to the fix for Bug #1833205 (I did not verify
if it is true, but that one also is about component annotation in copy-
paste operations)

Cheers,
Dino.
-----------------------------------
```

title: Wishlist: ERC options to test for unused symbol units (lp:#1839250)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1839250) created by **Rene Poeschl (poeschlr)**
```
Right now ERC does not report if a unit of a symbol is not used. This
weakens the "pin not connected" check. I would suggest to add additional
checks for this.

- A check if a unit containing power input pins is not placed (generates an
error)
- A check if a unit containing input or bidirectional pins is not placed
(generates a warning, option to turn this of globally)
- A check if any unit is not placed (warning or at least "info", it should
really be possible to turn this off)
```
Original tags: eeschema erc

title: wishlist: tool options on tool button right click (lp:#1839245)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1839245) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
Preface:
Now to set a tool option in pcbnew you have to select the tool and use the
popup menu, find the item and set the correct options (as an example I'm
thinking about the routing options).
In programs like GIMP to set a tool option you double-click the tool
button.

Wish: add the tool button double-click action to set tool parameters.

A list of parameters that could be set in such a way is:

Selection tool: Set a selection filter (object based, not yet implemented
but in wishlist #1793216 and coming in kicad 6)
Show ratsnest: select curved/straight line for ratsnest
Push-n-shove router: open "interactive router settings" dialog
Line/circle/arc: Set default line parameters (not the layer that will be
the current layer)
Dimension: Line width, text width-height... (not the layer that will be the
current layer)

DRC button: Open board setup->DRC rules

Of course this is a minimal list and there will be a lot of things I did
not think about.

For eeschema the same could be done, for instance on the graphic line/text
toolbuttons to set default color/size etc.

The advantages of this method are that it is more intuitive than the
shortcuts (to use them you have to learn them), and faster than searching
the correct sub-menu.


Cheers,
Dino.
```

title: CAM output automation / CAM manager combining all plotting and manufacturer data creation (lp:#1838987)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1838987) created by **Rene Poeschl (poeschlr)**
```
From https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1808013/comments/2 (It was
suggested to spawn a wishlist bug as the reported problem has been fixed.)

---

Long-term suggestion: Get rid of the current plot dialog and create a new
CAM output dialog combining gerber generation, drill file generation and
position file generation. (And possibly also some other things)

It is quite confusing right now. If i want to create gerber why would i not
want the drill file to be created. Yes i will want to have the same
settings available as with the drill dialog right now but some of them
should only be setable in one place. One example would be the use of the
auxilary origin. If it is enabled in gerber then i will want it in the
drill and position file as well.

Some of the current plot features could be either export or print options
(export to svg instead of plot to svg. Print to pdf instead of plot pdf.)
Or we could decide that they are simply other datatypes for the CAM export.

Such a CAM dialog could then also handle exporting and importing CAM
settings. And handle future more powerful data types (successors for
gerber)
```

description:

```
Pressing M to move a label or symbol in eeschema sometimes moves mouse
cursor to the bottom edge of the screen. Sometimes the cursor immediately
```

title: Symbol chooser window sets copy/paste focus to main window instead of property text boxes (lp:#1838708)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1838708) created by **Dan Green (danngreen)**
```
Copy/paste in eeschema is great, but I found it sometimes gets mixed up
when I'm copying text (like library:symbol name) and instead gets a
component data ($Comp... etc.) on the clipboard.

I think I narrowed it down to the Symbol chooser window changing the source
of Copy when using the main menu bar (but not the contextual pop-up menu).

To replicate (tested only on OSX):

1) Open any schematic
2) Open the Symbol Properties window for any symbol
3) Click the icon for "Browse Library" which opens the Choose Symbol window
4) Close the Choose Symbol window by clicking Cancel
5) Select the text in any text box in the Symbol Properties window.
6) Select "Copy" from the main Edit menu, or press Cmd+C (if you right-
click or control-click and select Copy from the context menu, the bug will
not appear)
7) Press Cmd+V to Paste: the entire symbol will be pasted into the
schematic window (rather than the text you selected being pasted into the
text box). Or, go over to your favorite text editor and hit Paste: you'll
see $Comp...$EndComp is in the clipboard instead of the text you had
selected when doing the Copy.
```

title: Misleading "Update footprints" text in "Update PCB from Schematic" (lp:#1838551)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1838551) created by **eelik (eelik)**
```
The "Update PCB from Schematic" dialog - opened from eeschema or pcbnew -
has an option "Update footprints". The UI text is misleading. I have seen
at least two threads in the user forum where a poster was confused by that,
trying to update footprint(s) on a board after modifying the footprint
module files.

The confusion comes from using the word "update" in two completely
different contexts with footprints. What the "Update PCB from Schematic"
dialog actually does is change (or not) the footprints if the footprint
associations, i.e. footprint names, have been changed in symbols of the
schematic. I think the UI text should reflect that. The word "update"
should in my opinion be reserved for updating from the changed library
file.

I would even go as far as to say that the dialog UI text could be "Don't
change footprints" or "Keep old symbol/footprint associations" or something
like that, and the default would be not selected.

In the minimum it should have a tooltip text which explains what it does.
Now none of the Options has a tooltip.
```

title: More links to config dialogs (lp:#1838550)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1838550) created by **Barry Buelow (iabarry)**
```
Running 5.1.2

Some time ago, I suggested a change to the drop down for PCBNew that added
the link to "Edit pre-defined sizes". IMHO This was a nice feature.  Thanks
for doing it.

Now I suggest that other similar functions have links to configuration
setting pages. This is a bit of a philosophical design change, but has the
potential to provide a more friendly user experience.

For example, on the "DRC Control" popup screen, it would be REALLY
CONVENIENT to have a button there to jump to the page (popup, whatever)
that configures the Rules. This may require multiple buttons depending on
the number of setup parameter locations.

This is not quite context sensitive help screens (which is also a great
idea), but rather an assist to both noobs and experienced users alike.

Sorry I'm not a dev, but I'd be happy to help if I can.

Barry
```

```
remapped then these definitions are still read in and can not be removed

gets an error every time the schematic is opened.
```
